Great video, but I have a question about the end. How is it "another example of how evolution finds radical solutions"? Is there another creature genetically similar, that has evolved a slightly different version of this? Like, let's say, without the underwater part? Another evolutionary branch of this technique, or perhaps the evolutionary ancestor of this? It should probably be quite simple to identify, since it's a fly larva (a relatively simple creature). Is there a common ancestor of the caddisfly and spiders with their silk?

It seems fairly odd to discuss the process, and then credit it to "evolution" without touching on anything else evolutionary. I'm just having a tough time determining how this instinct and capability would come into being from a random, accidental mutation of genes. How would the creature survive underwater without this adaptation, or, how would the caddisfly evolve this out of water and then decide to begin living underwater after it developed this ability?

Maybe "nature" would've been a better word choice than "evolution"? A little less presumptuous, and a little more scientific, y'know?

The larva already has chitin in it's DNA code, so why not use that instead of evolving to produce super glue, notions for size and shape of blocks, needed for building a 3 dementional case around itself? Also how did this evolve? At 1st its saliva was just a little bit sticky and it could build less effective shelters with oddly sized rocks and logicly it was not effective, yet it kept trying for milions of years until natural selection tought it how to do it? Geting the anatomical tools and the skills to do it over  night is not an option, so it must have been a futile efford for a loooong time. Why did it keep pushing and HOW did it survive when it wasnt effective? I could never understand complex outcomes like this. I've been researching Caddisflies for a Biomimicry class assignment and learned that in addition to shape and size, they are also selecting for texture. Caddisflies need a smooth interior shell to circulate oxygen for respiration inside the case, so the smoother the stones, the less silk required to adhere the case pieces together. If they have to build with rough surface textures, they do, but it requires coating the entire inside with more layers of silk to make it smooth. So in addition to being very skillful builders, they are also incredibly efficient in their building process.
